text: 22 ounce bottle. Translucent dark brown color. Big frothy tan head with good lacing. Roasted malt aroma hints at molasses, coffee and chocolate tootsie pops. Flavorful roasted maltiness. Chocolate, coffee, pepper and resiny hops. Finish has spicy hops and warming alcohol.
Backlog, ocena przepisana z untappd, w ramach uzupełniania profilu na ratebeer.

Tasted from bottle. Pours black with off white head. Aroma is coffee, chocolate and some citrus. Taste is more dominated by the roasted malts with moderate bitterness. Flavors of chocolate, coffee, licorice, pepper, citrus, floral notes. Pretty complex overall. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Graham cracker, cocoa, chocolate and tons of Malts. Biscuits and brown sugar. Tons of flavor. Super tasty. Black pour from 22oz bottle at Lakehouse.
Pours a deep dark amber color. Aromas of big hop action, sweet malts, and more hops. Flavor has some bready maltsy tastes with nice grapefruit and floral hop taste.

Pours dark black with light tan head. A faint aroma of chocolate, malts, and some light floral hops. A nice balanced taste of chocolate, coffee, malts, and hops. A mixed aftertaste of sweet chocolate and light bitter hops.

Sampled from a 22 oz brown bottle this beer poured a black color with a huge foamy tan head that lingered and left decent lacing. The aroma was bitter with anise, chocolate and floral hops. The flavor was leafy floral and fruity hops with roasty malts, anise, perfume and a bit of black food coloring. Long finish. Moderately full bodied. Meh.

75cl bottle. Dark brown pour with a medium height tan head. Smells like caramel, pine, milk chocolate, milk coffee. Smooth mouthfeel with a very well balanced taste. Notes of milk chocolate, coffee, bitter hops, pine resin and some nice roasted malts in the aftertaste. Excellent.
bottle at home from brewshop bristolfresh, orange and pine, low roast, chocolate, smooth, moderate carbonation, easy drinking, fruity, moderate pith, low carbonation, high fruity aroma, excellent

65cl bottle, served in Irish pint. Pours deep dark brown with medium tan head. Aroma is mocha, caramel and hints of citrus. Taste is the same, more dark chocolate notes than coffee, and the hop touch is earthy and herbal. Not too bitter, lingering though. Medium/full body, good carbonation. Nice Black Ipa.

Nearly black with thick tan froth. Strong hop aroma, dark chicolate and grapefruit. Flavour has juicy grapefruit, hard roasted malt and chocolate. Salty licorice as well, barely balancing the alcohol.

Very dark brown and almost black body with a nice, three centimetre tall oatmeal tan coloured head. Aroma of bright grassy and resinous hops, some alcohol, quite a bit of malt and even more dank reesin notes. Medium to Full-bodied; Strong rich roasted malt flavour coupled with some coffee and chocolate flavours on the finish, coupled with a dense chewy mouthful of hops, earth and roasted oatmeal. Aftertaste is nice and rich with the malt and especially the resinous and grassy hops coming through along with some alcohol and sweetness from oatmeal and grains. Overall, a nicely balanced, very rich black IPA that almost borders on an American Strong, but this shows good throughout. I sampled this 65 cL bottle purchased from Leukens Liqour in Dunedin, Florida on 03-October-2015 for US$9,99 sampled in my hotel room in Columbia, Maryland on 07-December-2015.

Bomber. Curious Hop, Otley. Clear, dark brown. Dense, sticky, gingery tan coloured, lasting head. Looks great. Nose has rich, dark, orange chocolate. Pine needle. Thick, dark sugars. Some toasted nuts. Taste has some charred, pine wood bitterness. Bonfire toffee sweetness balances nicely. Smooth, unctuous and super drinkable. Finishes long, moderate, roasted, resinous bitter. Fantastic.

Bottle shared in Canaan, NH. Thanks to Duke. Pours black-brown with a frothy khaki head. Big roast nose, cocoa, se burnt pine, dark fruits. Medium sweets flavor, some sugary chocolate, scorched earth, brownies, oily pine. Medium to full bodied with average carbonation. Subtly resinous to finish, some burnt graham crackers, grass, booze, chocolate. Not bad overall.

Black, medium white head. Delightful mix of US hops (a proper punch) and roasty, cocoa maltiness. Mix of sweet and bitter, medium body. Cocoa and hops. This shouldnt mix well - and yet it does. Wonderous.

Medium beige head. Opaque black body. Roasty earthy chocolatey aroma with citric spicy notes. Dry roasty chocolatey taste with burnt earthy notes. Mid-to-full body. Mild, mealy mouthfeel. Dryish mealy earthy minty aftertaste with citric chocolate notes. Good, drinkable, reasonably harmonic. (0.65l bottle, from Fish & Beer, Copenhagen.)

650 mL bottle. Pours stout brown with not much head. More black than IPA in the nose. Flavour is way bigger than youd think from the nose. Great malty complexity - anise stands out. The hops are there, put the flavours are muddled. The malt makes this one a standout.

65cl bottle enjoyed @ home. Pours opaque dark brown with a medium sized tan head. Aroma is chocolate, roasted malt, pine, citrus, coffee, liquorice. Flavour is medium bitter, salty and quite roasted. Medium to full bodied, creamy texture, average carbonation. Finish is grassy bitternes and roasted malt.

UPDATED: APR 19, 2015 Bottle 65cl / Botella 65cl.
@ Cervezorama 2.0.
A: Black / Negro.
T/S: Roasted malt, hops, sweet, licorice / Malta tostada, lupulo, dulce, regaliz.
Bottle at home. I do love hoppin frog, pours black, taste is smooth, roast, fruity flavour.

Rated on 4-07-2013. This bottled beer has a medium sized smooth tan head that mostly diminished, opaque dark brown body and spotty amounts of lacing. The aroma is roasted malt, chocolate and pine hops. The flavor is pine hops, lightly bitter, roasted malt, chocolate, and alcohol. The mouthfeel is lively and this beer is medium bodied. This beer is very quaffable, has a hop presence but not overly hoppy tasting and is worth trying.

Bottle from sfhodense. Near black with a small off white head. Hoppy aroma of citrus and pine, with licorice and caramel. Dry and roasted flavour with lots of hop character and a bitter finish. This is tasty!

Dark brown, nice sift of tan head. Punchy grapefruit and molasses nose, bright squeaky roast. Fairly straight-laced, squeaky roast again, simple clementine juicy push before the bitterness towards the finish. Creamy and clean throughout. Linger is light, caramac sweet. Bottle.

Bottle at Pedale, Madrid, May 2013Black color. Very nice aroma of roasted malt and hops, with light glue, resins, cardboard, milk. Good body strength; it has a very good roasted malt flavor, not too strong, with dark chocolate, mild coffee, barley coffee, light cream, a hint of oak and tobacco. Nice hop resins to counterbalance the roastiness.Excellent, not the usual one, indeed it adds something to the concept.

On tap at CBC 2014. Beer in the glass deep black, small head. Malty hoppy aroma, a bit earthy. Starts well balanced malty, hoppy-spicy, more and more stouty. Well balanced finish, dominated by strong malty notes. Nice!

Very nice beer to see. Almost black in the glass. From tap at Biercab. 
Taste with caramel, coffee and a complex nose.
Bottle at Kittys, Helsinki. Colour is dark brown with small brownish white head. Aromas and flavours: Licorice, grain, some coffee and roasted malts.

22 oz bottle. The Kitty's, Helsinki, Finland. 
The aroma is black colour with a tiny head.
Liquorice, sweetness, seaweed and medicine in the aroma. 
The flavour is liquorice, bready malt, mild hops and mild bitterness. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Wow! Incredibilemente buona una black IPA che regala in bocca un buonissimo sapore di liquirizia luppolato. Nera impenetrabile con schiuma marrone. Al naso sentori di luppolo, fumo e carruba. In bocca tutto sapore e benissimamente bilanciata. Birra pericolosa che nasconde benissimo il suo tenore alcolico. Consigliata assolutamente!

22 ounce bottle into tulip glass, no bottle dating. Pours pitch black color with a 2 finger dense khaki head with good retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Nice soapy lacing clings around the glass, with moderate streaming carbonation. Aromas of big grapefruit, tangerine, orange peel, citrus rind, dark chocolate, cocoa, roasted malt, coffee, light char, pine, floral, grass, and floral/roasted earthiness. Very nice aromas with good balance and complexity of citrus/grassy hops and balanced roasted malt sweetness; with great strength. Taste of big grapefruit, tangerine, orange peel, citrus rind, dark chocolate, cocoa, roasted malt, coffee, light char, floral, grass, pine, and floral/roasted earthiness. Good amount of pine/roasted bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of grapefruit, orange zest, tangerine, citrus rind, dark chocolate, cocoa, roasted malt, coffee, light char, pine, floral, grass, and floral/roasted earthiness on the finish for a while. Fantastic complexity and robustness of citrus/pine hops and roasted malt sweetness; with a great roasted malt/hop flavor balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Medium carbonation and medium-full bodied; with a moderately creamy and fairly sticky/chalky mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is very well hidden with only a slight warming present after the finish. Overall this is an awesome imperial black IPA. All around great complexity and balance of citrus/pine hops and robust roasted malt flavors; and very smooth to sip on for the ABV. A highly enjoyable offering.

text: 22 oz. bottle from Homer321 - thanks again! Figures he sends an Ohio bottle that I havent seen on shelves since I moved back to Ohio. Anyway, this one pours an almost jet black color with a finger of creamy khaki head that laces the glass heavily. Aroma of dark chocolate, earthy and herbal hops, roasted malts, faint peppery spice, toast, and burnt sugar. The hops take a while to open up, but once they do, they have a much different character than most other black IPAs. Flavor of chocolate, roasted and toasted malts, tobacco, earth, and cocoa powder. Light-medium bodied, with a malty mouthfeel and moderate carbonation. Very soft on the palate, and drinks under its 8.8% ABV. This one took a while to reveal its charms. I had to keep upping my score.

Bottle from a store in Columbus, OH. 650ml. Shared with dad in snifters. Pours a very dark, mostly opaque with a one finger eggshell head. Head lasted awhile and solid lacing. The aroma was the traditional black IPA hops meets roasted malts. The hops were pine, resin and wet grass while the malts were roasty and chocolaty. The taste was a great balance between both hops and roasted malts with the finish being slightly bitter and pine. Medium body and carbonation. Seriously good black IPA.

Pour is black with ringed tan head. Good lacing. Aroma is pine, oak, some spice, dark chocolate and a whisper of coffee (aarghhh!!!). Medium body, beautiful velvety mouth-feel . Piney-Hop flavor takes a back seat to the charred malt. Coffee and dark chocolate. Fairly dry and soft roasted coffee-bitterness on the back-end. Akin to a light coffee-stout. Too much coffee, not enough hop-presence. Really not my thing.

Pours very dark. Aroma is malt, some hops and some dried fruit. Taste is a bit of malt sweetness at first and then a nice pop of piney hops. One of the best black IPAs Ive had the opportunity to taste.
Amazing beer. Very hoppy, yet also fruity, with a solid body of roasted malt. Very tasty and diverse. Great.

Tasty black ale, but probably would have been better fresher with more hop predominance.
Dark brown/amber color with small tan head and little lacing. Aroma and flavor have nice piney bitterness, light citrus, and a light toasted malt. Okay overall.
Pour from bomber. Very hoppy and lots of rye. Decent black IPA. Sort of on the thin side.

Bottle 650ml @Beer Hunters

Pours pitch black with a thinner mocha-khaki head that leaves some small, spotty lace. Nose involves lots of dark chocolate, toast, fresh pine, milk chocolate, earth, stone fruit, biscuits, dank grapefruit, frosting, molasses and mango. Pretty sweet and pretty bitter. Medium to full bodied, thick and rich, sticky, oily, pretty actively carbed, with a lengthy drying bitter finish. Really damn good brew, a nice bold and complex mix. Among the best Ive had in the style.

Pours a dark brown beer with a good creamy tan head. Smells fruity, coffee. Tastes coffee, vanilla, fruity and roasty. Average carbo, medium body and a sticky texture.

Bottle @ ZZT 8 shared by Abijen. Opaque pitch black color, medium sized brown head that diminishes fairly quickly. Aroma has malts, very hoppy, lightly roasty. Taste malts, hops, moderately grapefruit, light to moderately roasty and nicely bitter. Medium body and carbonation. Delicious!

FROM NOTES: August 7, 12
Poured from a 22 ounce bottle into a Spiegelau tulip. 

A: Roasted malts and chocolate notes dominate the aroma initially, but a strong piney, citrus hop profile reveals itself quickly. Smells fantastic. 
A: Pours a very dark near-black, with some brownish/ruby highlights and a tan foam head that settles to a thin cap and splotchy lacework.
T: Delicate but successful balance between the hops and malts. Nice and hoppy with a fair amount of sweetness. There is also a strong amount of chocolate and roast with a equally as strong amount of hops. 
P: Medium in body and moderate carbonation. 
O: I tried to find fault with this beer, but it is excellent. The chocolate, roasty malt notes set it apart from other American Black Ales. If you like Black Ale, you MUST try this, IMO.

A dark brown/black colored beer, with  beige head. The aroma is fruity, some sweet and roasted malt. The taste of fruits, dark roasted malt. notes of spices and some wood. The aftertaste is sweet with bitter roasted malt and chocolate notes.

Thanks to 5000 for sending me this bottle. Pours a black color with a tan head. The aroma is full of roasted malt with some resinous pine from the hops. The flavor is more of the same. I get some pine, roasted malt and chocolate malt. Creamy mouthfeel and medium carbonation.

28th August 2012Opaque black beer, good sized pale tan head. Piney hop nose. Smooth palate, slightly viscous. Nice fine carbonation. Smooth but pretty skunky hops, fair bit of pine too. Smooth mild dark malt, a little cream. No roast or bitterness. Finishes smooth and piney. Nice sumptuous Black IPA - just a bit much with the skunk.
Bottle. Clear black with big brown head. Aroma roasted, caramel, burn, hop. Flavor caramel, roasted, hop, burn.

Bottle courtesy of Kermis at the NS Tasting 2. Poured a deep mahogany colour with a thick tan creamy coffee like head. The aroma is rich bitter and dry malty. The flavour is big bitter, with lots of liqourice and dark chocolate,  The palate is lovely and smooth.

Bottle shared at NS tasting #2.  Pours dark brown with a thick beige head.  Aroma of caramel, fudge, roasted malt, oats and milk chocolate.  Flavour is light heavy sweet and light medium bitter.  Medium bodied with soft carbonation.

Sample at ns tasting 2.
Thick tan head.  Clear black pour.  Nixe smooth bitterness.  Lovely brew
Wow. Definitely the best black ipa I have tried. Aroma is full of sweet malt and hops. Pours black with a tan head. Medium bodied finishes smooth.

Pours cola brown with a cream-colored creamy head.  Aroma of hops, pine,roasted malt, and chocolate.  Creamy mouthfeel with chocolate, roasted malt, pine, and a slight hop bite.  Might be the best Black IPA Ive tried.

Dark brown and clear with a light brown foam. Good mix aroma of smoke, chocolate, pine, and lemongrass. Medium body with a tasty spiciness, Dark malts leave a smoky wood flavor on the palate.Very well put together.

Bomber. A clear dark brown to black beer, topped by an average sized, frothy, lacing. almost fulluy lasting, light brown head. The aroma is moderately to heavily malty (roasted grain, toasted/roasted nuts, chocolate, caramel hint of coffee), moderately hoppy (resin, pine needles, grapefruit), with notes of wood, smoke. The flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly to moderately bitter. Medium to full body, creamy texture, soft/lively carbonation, very long finish with moderate bitterness, lightly to moderately alcoholic. A very solid, even balanced beer. with lots of dark malts and a good amount of green hops. Less bitterness than expected, with well hidden alcohol and excellent, smooth mouthfeel, all but abrasive and almost refined. Solid brewery.

Bottle on Easter. Pours black with off white head. Nose and taste of cocoa, pine, resin, the white part of a grapefruit, dark roasted malts and bakers chocolate. Finishes bakers chocolate with slight resin. Medium body.

Pours black with a tall tan head.
Rich aroma of chocolate, roast malt and coffee liqueur.
The flavor has some roast malt bitterness balanced by the coffee sweetness.  I think this beer will be a love it or hate it. Dont bother if you dont like any bitterness, but for those who like em big and bold - go for it.
Better than many barrel aged brews.
Smell of hops and herbs. Dark brown colour, brown head. First taste is porter. This is seriously more porter than IPA. Roasted Malts. No real tastes initially, but ends up sweet.

Pours dark brown with a beige head of foam that quickly gives way to a ring leaving spotty lacing behind. Aroma is rich dark malt, pinecone hops, and light roasted chocolate. Taste is piney hops, roasted malt, and a tad of black coffee on the end of the short juicy finish.

Bottle: &nbsp Pours black, deep brown highlights, moderate to large foamy pale brown head, nice lacing. &nbsp Soft hop and roasted malts on the nose, slight touch of bakers or dark chocolate. &nbsp Neither a big roasty example or a bitter IPA, at least from the nose. &nbsp Seems a bit more robust and lively on the tongue, more roasty and hoppy than the nose suggested. &nbsp Good balance between the two. &nbsp The dark chocolate aspect is there, not as big as the nose suggested. &nbsp Body and mouthfeel are moderate. &nbsp Finishes with a good balance, hoppy with a nice soft dark chocolate roasted malt background. &nbsp Solid example!

Sampled at Fort Wayne rating party - Pours near black and smells of dark roast malt, chocolate, and some hops in the background. It has a vinous flavor with dark roast malts joined by ample hops bitterness. Medium to full bodied, its a superb brew.

Location: 22 oz bottle from State Line, 3/12/13


Aroma: The nose has some grapefruit hops, roasted malts, and a bit of pine as well

Appearance: It pours a dark brown-black color with a small brown head and fairly coating lace

Flavor: The flavor is mid-heavy bitter/hoppy, with some nice balancing from the roasted malts

Palate: The body is medium-full, it feels slightly chewy, a little thick, and with a dry finish

Overall Impression: 
This is a nice Black IPA.  It does a really good job of mixing a strong hop feel with a good amount of roasted malt flavor.  Good stuff.

Bottle @ home.....It pours clear jet black with a medium creamy tan head.... The aroma is heavy hoppy, roasted malt, citrus and some licorice....The flavor is  hoppy, piney, citrus, grass and fruits.....

Bottle at home ... deep black ... small tan head ... soft dark roast ... light pine hop ... dark roast ... soft sweet pine ... really nice but as it sits breathing ,,, soft caramel toffee malts come out that im much less fond of.

Thin light brown head from a pretty vigorous pour.  Lots of hoppy goodness in the aroma with lots of pine, strong vanilla, licorice and a good helping of malt.  Not much roastyness which is what I would have expected.  Color is a very dark brown.  More piney hops in the flavor along with some sweet malts, dried flowers and mild bittersweet chocolate.  Not overly bitter or dry.  A nice balance of dark malts and hops.  Light alcohol presence which you feel more than taste.  Kind of milky mouthfeel at times.  Finishes roasty and creamy with some vanilla.  A pretty damn good black IPA.

This is what I would expect of a Black IPA. It combines the roasty malts of a stout with the hoppiness of an IPA. Pours almost black with a thin lacing head. The aroma has chocolate and roast malt with a hint of the hops to come. The flavor begins with the malt and chocolate but gives way to a intense bitterness. Quite nice and refreshing, the big ABV is well hidden.

22oz bomber from Spirits Brick. Poured a pitch black solid body of medium/fuller density with a smaller foamy beige head that fades and leaves some weird pools of laden the top of the body. Aroma is toasty, dark burnt chocoalte, burnt toast, grapefruit and some pineapple, earth,  with some fruit sugar sweetness towards the end. Medium mouthfeel with average/fuller carbonation and a long lingering burnt roasting and op bitterness on the end. Flavor is actually as good I f not a bit better than the aroma. Notes of burnt toast, burnt dark chocolate,yellow grapefruit rind, earth, bark, dark malts, some burnt tropical fruit rinds. Very nicely done HF, good stuff.
black pour with a small head. Aroma of toffee, weed, mint, and herbal spiciness. Flavor is kind of fucked. It almost has that green homebrew beer taste, similar mouthfeel too. Not feeling it anymore.

22oz bomber courtesy of BMMillsy. It pours nearly pitch black with an impressive lasting light mocha colored head of foam. The aroma is interesting and seems odd with earthy hops, some anise and then mild chocolate and dark roasted malts mingling together a bit less than harmoniously. Smells a bit odd but its growing on me. The taste comes across rich and viscous and delivers dark roasted malts, some chocolate, spicy black licorice and then getting into a modest degree of resiny bitter hops. This is nice but it doesnt hit a home run for me.

(22oz bomber thanks to mora2000) clearish medium brown, soapy tan bubbles. Nose of rich honey, milk chocolate, balanced towards malt, decadent. Taste of chocolate malt, milk chocolate, honey and caramel. Excellent rich linger.

650ml bottle from Cotteridge Wines.Poured a lovely black colour with a minimal tan head.Roast malt aroma with some chocolate and a hint of hop.Nice roast malt and chocolate flavour with the hops again being hinted at.Smooth,balanced and with a nice chocolatey ending on warming a little further down the bottle makes for a very enjoyable beer.

Black with a thin tan head. Aroma is big roasted chocolate malt. Slight hops in the nose. Flavor is strong roasted malt, definite notes of dark chocolate. Hops come through in the finish to add an almost spicy note to accent the chocolate. Reminded me of dark chocolate with chili without the burning. Really enjoying this.

Une Black IPA comme celle-là , cest inoubliable ! des notes grillées, agréablement caramélisé.; un gout de chocolat très fin, du houblon sur du floral, raisins trempés dans lalcool.. Cest fondant et on en redemande !

Poured a nice black, dark brown at edges, decent head.  Aroma was chocolate, with a nice burst of spruce and grapefruit hops.  Flavor is a match.  Well balanced between the roast and hop notes.  Very good.

Pours black with tan head.  Aroma is dark fruits, roasted malts, a little chocolate.  Taste follows suit with chocolate and roastiness, finished with raisiny/datey taste.  Palate is thick and satisfying.  Good stuff.

I try a new Hoppin Frog whenever I can. Hoppin to Heaven IPA is by far my favorite but, Heathen is a great beer. The one word I think of is balanced. There is a definite hop and malt profile and neither overpowers the other. Highly Recommend. My only minus is that there isnt a distinct aroma that set it apart.
1 pt 6 fl. oz bottle @ Vihreä Haltiatar. Pours pitch black with a low tan head. Aroma is roasted malts, alcohol and fruits. Flavor is roasted malts, coffee, fruits and a hoppy finish. Very good.

Bottle 650ml @ home
Pours black with a tan head. Aroma has notes of roasted malt, citrus, grape and chocolate. Taste is medium sweet and medium to heavy bitter with a long chocolate and citrus fruity finish. Body is full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

Black as night, a very roasty version of the style.  The taste is a range of roast, nutty, hop presence but not so IPA.
Freshly ordered from Lueken.
Bottle. Black colour with a tan head. Aroma is hop, roasted malt, chocolate, coffee. Flavour is hop, roasted malt, citrus, chocolate, coffee, spices. Very nice beer.

Pours black into an English pint. Mocha head with medium retention recedes leaving spider lacing to mottle surface. Dark chocolate and espresso aromas. Medium bodied with sweet chocolate and caramel upfront turning dry in the lasting hot espresso finish.
(bottle 04-01-2012) low light brown head, clear dark red almost black color, hoppy aroma, dry hop taste, slightly roasted taste, some bitterness.

Bottle at CP&K. It pours very dark brown with medium light tan head. The nose is pine, liquorice, roasted malt, rye bread, orange peel and molasses. The taste is roasted malt, pine, resin, ash, citrus, salted caramel, liquorice, molasses and touch of alcohol warmth with a bitter finish. Medium body, moderate carbonation and slightly sticky mouth-feel. Balance is spot on. Pretty damn flavoursome.

Black with clear red tinted edges and kakki head that sticks to the glass. Spicy hop aroma mingled with caramel, chocolate and a touch of roast. Medium-bodied, smooth, yet very drinkable. Rich and malty, chocolatey with a boost of hop flavor and finishing with enough bitterness to balance. No roast astringency. One of the best balanced black IPAs with the best mingling of hops and chocolate malt. A great example of this emerging style.

Name: Hop Heathen
Date: November 13, 2012
Mode: Bottle
Source: Hop City, Atlanta
Appearance: black, fine tan head, streaks of lace
Aroma: big citrus aroma backed by roasted malt
Flavor: flavor starts of sweet followed by abundant citrus hops, balancing dark roast
Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 14/20
Rating: 3.5/5.0Drinkability: 7/10
Score: **+ /4

Tämä jo lasiin kaatuessaan pakanaksi tuomittu olut näyttäytyy mustana muodostaen beigen vaahdon. Sen tuoksu on suklainen, paahtunut, lakritsinen ja eksoottisen hedelmäinen. Tuoksu tuo mieleen karkkipussin, jonka sisältö on lakritsaista, hedelmäistä ja ehkä hieman salmiakkistakin. Maku on paahtunut, suklainen, makea, lakritsinen, mentholinen, katkera ja hieman hedelmäinenkin. Makukin on makeismainen, mutta tuo mieleen enemmän yskänpastilleja kuin tuoksu. Suutuntuma on erittäin pehmeä ja täyteläinen. Toimii ainakin minulle paremmin kuin useimmat black ipat.

22 oz bottle courtesy of Chris, to kick off the weekend, served in a plastic cup in the parking lot. Pours chestnut-black with a moderate tan head that slowly fades to a thin cover. The nose has big, piney, resinous hops paired with chocolate and roasted coffee beans. The flavour is quite bitter, with resin the most dominant feature. Resin and pine linger through a moderate length finish. On the palate, it is medium-full in body with a thick, creamy texture. Overall, this is quite a nice black IPA. The creamy texture was a beautiful highlight, but the hops were nice too. 2012-06-08

Bottle @ tasting. Black pour, thin tan head. Aroma is floral hops, somewhat sweaty, spicy and roasty butb with the hops definitely more prominent. Flavor is bitter roasted, chocolate, floral hops, some pine and a bit sweaty. Decent black IPA, but I still dont really like the style.
Bottle @ tasting. Aroma is big american hops, some roasty caramel. Flavour is roasty malt, some chocolate, medium hop bitterness, mostly roasty malt bitterness. Good, but a bit weird mix of flavours.

Bottled sample via and shared with oakbluff. Near black in colour with medium carbonation. Aromas are of milk chocolate, vanilla, molasses and ginger. Flavors are of lean pale malt, caramel, earthy hops, and lightly roasted coffee. Medium bodied. Solid, but could be more bitter and hoppy.
650 ml bottle. Aroma smoked and roasted, nice. Tastes rich and a bit tangy. Dark but not burned, with a nice bitter finish.
Pours clear dark brown color with tan head. Aromas of roasted malts and citrus. Dark roasted malt flavor with some chocolate and citrus. Medium body with moderate carbonation.

In short: A rich, heavy and very sticky hoppy dark ale.  A Tasty treat even if a bit rough and sticky
How: Bottle 22oz, consume fresh exactly one week after purchase
The look: Dark mahogany body topped by a long-lasting small beige head
In long: The intense nose is resinous hops, black liquorice, pan-fried hazelnuts.
Taste is fudge nougat, cashews, highly resinous leafy hops, toasted beach wood sensation, fruity notes of grapes, forest floor, tree sap, green pine needles, vanilla, grapefruits, tobacco.  Very sticky bitterness.  Full body with a medium carbonation. Lots of things happening here, this is a tasty beer for sure and a style I like, but I found this one a bit too sticky, good but not very good.  Still drinking the full bomber was rather easy, and I love to enter a rating for a strong beer and say I drank the whole bottle by myself, just to show-off how badass I am, and then I go take a nice long bubble bath.

66cl bottle from Toftvin. No BBD. Pours black with medium tan head. Some retention and decent lace. Aroma is floral hops and the starchy character remniscient of black IPAs. Creamy texture, soft carbonation, full body with a hoppy and slightly roasted finish. Taste is well balanced, with a pleasant bitterness complemented by the moderate sweetness accentued by mildly roasted background character. Alltogether smooth and pleasant.

22 oz. bottle, sent from jmikolich (thanks Jim), pours near-black with a small tan head. Aroma of rich roasted malts, lots of harsh dry hops, and some sweet caramel malt. Flavour is well-balanced between the roasted malt and hops, perhaps more on the sweet side for an Imperial Black IPA, with caramel and roasted malt upfront, with a healthy hop dose in back. Sweet, roasty finish, without any astringency. Light-to-medium bodied for the style, without any harshness. Good stuff, but overrated I feel.

bottle.  black pour with small tan head.  strong piney, soily earth and toasted aroma.  robust roasted character with that same earthy note.  hops are maxed out with strong pine notes.  tastes like a chocolate pillow mint.  big presence, bold, full bodied, long earthy aftertaste.  warming finish.  nice beer for CDA fans.

Bottle 65 cl. Cloudy opaque dark brown with a creamy beige head, good retention and lace. Aroma is sweet roasted malts with an some citrusy hops and a licoricy note. Aroma is sweet roasty with licorice and a little chocolate, medium bitter finish.

Bottle at ÖÖWF cons 2012-11-17 Örebro
AR: roasted malt. Tropical fruits, fudgy,caramel
AP: watery pitch black,thin creamy beige head
F: roasted malt, fudgy, wee grain, à bit of wood, buttery

Pours near black. Aroma of smoked malt taste of anisette. High alcohol.  Clean after taste.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bomber. Very dark pour with a spotty foamy off white head. Roasty, coffee, chocolate, with some spicy hop bite. Excellent.

Pours coffee black with a thin mocha head. Smell is nice...mellow...hops and caramel.  Tastes sweet....hoppy...some alcohol.  Nice on the palate...kind of thin with a small hoppy bite on the end of the taste.

65cl bottle courtesy of Belgbeergeek @ Belgian RB Gathering of Ultimate Evil.
Couleur foncée/noire, col épais crémeux café au lait/moka.
Arôme est superbement bien houblonné allant presque vers un poivré/pin et cela tellement le houblon est ici mis en usage. Note en parallèle le malt chocolaté qui contribue à ce style.

Palais présente un profile profond de malt laissant des notes chocolatées qui se marient parfaitement avec un profile houblonné épicé presque de piment/poivre, résineux avec un léger citronné pour une amertume en parfaite harmonie avec la base malt.
Peut aussi y noter des notes de café, cône de pin, épices, fleuri et chocolat en poudre. Le plus marquant de la bière étant ce côté quasi épicé pimenté qui ne gâche pas lexpérience mais donne une belle dimension et cela à chaque gorgées.

bottle from Roman , thanks again ! 
Head: espresso 
Colour: black 
Smell: hops , quite spicey, a bit creamy, peppery 
Taste: start is somewhat herbal and bitter with nice american hops in the palate, quite easly drinkable ( as allot of BIPAs arent ), very refsrehing and at the same time warming , as in good for winter times ,some chocolate and malts, overall a very good brew , my hopes werent set high , but i was wrong ! Delicious !

Bottle. Totally black, beautiful beige head with good retention and solid lacing. Aroma of bright pine on a background of bitter cocoa. Taste starts sweet and roasty, then dry and bitter cocoa, espresso, pine. Delicious.

Bedankt Belgbeergeek. 66 cl. fles gedeeld met Belgbeergeek & Sebletitje @ Belgian Ratebeer Winter Gathering of Ultimate Evil. Donker bruin met een kleine mokka kraag. Geur heeft heel veel zwarte peper, redelijk wat kruiden, Amerikaanse hop hars, chili chocolade, pikant met wat chili, fascinerend, komt dicht echt hoor enkel dankzij zonder hop, gemakkelijk de meest interestante en beste Hoppin Frog bier tot nu toe. Smaak is zoete chocolade, beetje room vermeng met zwarte peper, kleverig, wat hars maar echt heel hars hoppig is dit ook weer niet, donker fruit, cacao, lichte aardse hop op het einde. Gemakkelijk een van de beste Black IPAs die ik tot nu toe gehad heb.

Draught at Örebro Beer&Whisky Festival 2012. Dark brown beer with a nice beige head. Hoppy aroma, roasted, milk chocolate, cocoa powder, citrus, licorice, perfume, pine, woody, some ash, some alcohol. Hoppy roasted flavor, chocolate, cocoa powder, creamy, hay, citrus, raisins, lemongrass, soot, perfume notes, vanilla. Complex and full bodied, with a nice chocolate finish, hay, cocoa, licorice and pine. Really nice!

Black. Has a an off-white head, medium duration. Heavy hoppy aroma, citrus, heavy rubber, soft and dark malts too. Roasted flavor, sweetness to a start, then heavy hoppy bitterness to a finish. Dry, dry texture with a moderate creamy note too.
nice sweet chocolate aroma,black, brown foam, light sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, oily feel, bitter, long finish,

This bottled brew from a rating party poured a head of foamy finely sized tan colored bubbles that were long lasting and left behind a semi-opaque dark ruby red brown colored body and an excellent lacing. The aroma was raisin musty and dark malt. The mouth feel was tingly at the start and at the finish. The flavor contained notes of mild hops and dark malt. A decent one that I would consider drinking again.

Bottle on Amtrak Train 27 - The Empire Builder ( from Binnys South Loop) - 05/11/12.
Mid black with a big frothy tan head that retains well. Good lacing ensues.
Light roast malt on the nose, chocolate, liqourice, hops, treacle toffee, molasses and a touch of smoke.
Taste takes on all the charectaristics of the nose allied to light tropical fruit flavours, a little pine, touch of citrus.
Fuller end of medium bodied, soft carbonation, smooth drinking.
As much stout as CDA! Decent stuff none the less.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Nice black IPA all around here. Very rich and milk chocolatey with nice vibrant piney, herbal hops. Some muddled elements that drop it from the best black IPAs but its very good and worth trying for sure

Sampled at GABF 2012 with Andrew and Moreau. Pours a dark brownish black body with thin lacing. Aroma is spicy hop, pine and malt. Mouthfeel is meidum, well carbonated with notes of spice, pine hop and roasted malt. Very good Black IPA.

Nice black IPA all around here.  Very rich and milk chocolatey with nice vibrant piney, herbal hops.  Some muddled elements that drop it from the best black IPAs but its very good and worth trying for sure.
Great, rich and creamy and very bitter and hoppy, and a little soapy, chocolately

0.65 l bottle. Black color. Roasty and perfumed aroma with cocoa, roiboos, gun powder, ginger and orange. Sweet, roasty and softly bitter flavor with bitter chocolate with pepper, roiboos tea, ginger. Full soft body. Unique spicy character, hard to describe but I like it.

From Hophead, DK.
Bottled, 181012.
Black with beige head. Aroma of roasted malt. Flavour with coffee, chocolate and hop spices.

Bottle. Pours black with thick tan head. Aroma is very nice, coffee, burnt toast, pine and grapefruit. Taste doesnt quite live up to the aroma, quite roasty, some muddled hops, caramel. A tad on the thin side with a moderately bitter finish. Nice

Dark beer with a thin beige head out of the bottle.  Chocolate malt nose with some hop resin.  Flavors of milk chocolate, fudge and alcohol with some fruit.  There are some hop balance but I got mostly the chocolate out of this beer.

Pours murky swamp brownish black in color with a beige head. The aroma brings the hops up front, like fresh herbs for sure with a bit of sweet herbiness as well. The flavor is fresh herbal hops as well, so smooth for a higher ABV with a smooth somewhat creamy body. This bottle is really fresh and juicy, quite delicious.

Bottle at home.
Black coloured with a medium sized off-white head.
Fruity and light roasted aroma of caramel, hops, grass, licorice and petroleum.
Fruity and light roasted flavour of caramel, licorice, hops, dark chocolate and citrus peel.
Hoppy finish.

22oz bottle in a tulip.  Pours very dark brown with a lacy, beige head.  Aroma of lots of citrusy hops and roasted and chocolatey malts.  Flavor the same, with a lot of everything.  Smooth texture.  A really good beer.

Aroma is fruits, liquorice, some grassy hops as well as mild earthyness. Flavour is chocolate, liquorice, some mild toffee, fruits, grass and floral notes. Nice aftertaste.

Tallahassee, Fl - Proof Bottle Shop - 22 oz bomber. Pours a dark brown/jet black with a sticky khaki colored head. Aroma leaves a bit to be desired. Deep brown pour, probably one SRM off from black with a small tan head and some decent lacing. Pungent, sticky, dank, dry-esque hops with underlying roasted and coffee malts. Pours an opaque black from the bomber with a thin tan head and moderate lacing. Aroma of roasted malts, pine from hops, and slight coffee notes. Taste is like a zesty, piney, roasted, almost burnt coffee, but well balanced and a bit of a burn on the way down from the alcohol. Good stuff.

Bomber from Proof.  Black pour with a light brown head and good retention.  Aroma is roasted malt, chocolate and pine.  Tastes are sweet burnt malts, coffee, juicy hops, salty and a chocolate milky vibe.  All of that is in fine balance with an even warm finish.  Medium bodied.  Very nice.  An easy drinking sipper.

Bottled at SBWF.  Near black, small head. Aroma of vanilla and grapefruit. Medium-full bodied with rounded mouthfeel. Under the hoppy nose rests dark chocolate and coffee as well as white pepper and licorice. Juicy citrus is interrupted by chili-like heat and alcohol in the finish.

Bottle. Very dark brown, hazy, average and mostly diminishing light brown head. Moderate malty and sweetish aroma, light caramel and light roasted malt with some tropical fruitiness, lots of grapefruit - piney hoppyness. Body is medium to full, malty and sweetish flavor, light caramel and some roasted malt, some fruitiness, lots of grapefruit - piney hoppyness. Finish is average to long, malty and lightly sweetish, light caramel and some roasted malt and lots of piney hoppyness. Really well hopped (black)IPA - not too sweet/too much caramel.

Smooth mouthfeel, medium bitterness.9/4/8/4/17=4.2RerateBottle thanks to Dunbar72! On Feb 22, 2014.Black color, small dark brown head. Sweet, hoppy, roasted scent. Sweet, malty, grainy, a bit hoppy taste. Smooth mouthfeel, medium bitterness.Rather lovely this one!9/4/9/4/19=4.5
UPDATED: DEC 5, 2016 Im not a big fan of the cascadian dark ales. Black malts need time and fresh hops is better.... But this one is explosive! Perfect Mix

Bottle (bomber) from bierkompass.de. Black with a red edge, medium beige head. Strong hoppy aroma with pine needles and apricot, som perfumy notes, dark chocolate and coffee. Meidum bodied, soft carbonation. Semi dry, medium bitterness.

Black IPAs confuse me and appeal to me at the same time this one is a good one they have decided to call it an Imperial Black Ale.  Loads of american hops in aroma which are present in the taste well balanced with chocolate roast malts.
Pissed.  Why is detroits bullpen so bad?  Drinking this beer supposedly to celebrate but nevermind.  We are going to give up three runs in the 9th.  Nice work.  Weee.

UPDATED: OCT 9, 2012 Bottled. Clear and deep brown with a huge, creamy and off-white to beige head. Good lacing. Nose of toasted malt, caramel, dark coffee, chocolate, citrus fruits pine and grassy notes. Sweet flavor with grapefruit and toasted caramel. Medium bodied, oily texture and soft to average carbonation. Ends up more dry with bitter chocolate and alcohol notes. A nice one from Hoppin Frog.

This was not my thing.  Bottle purchased and immediately refrigerated, drank about two weeks after purchase.  Very heavy burnt coffee taste, slight spicy hop note but muted by the overwhelming taste of charred malt.  Not outright BAD but also not good.

22 oz bottle.  Pours a clear brown body with a small tight bubbled beige head that left a bit of lacing.  The nose is balanced, leaning a bit toward the chocolate and roasted malts more than the slightly citrusy hops.  I could actually do with a little more hops for something called an Imperial Black IPA.  The flavor is much the same way, lots more chocolate and roast with a little bit of licorice up front.  The fairly moderate bitterness emerges on the finish.  On the lighter side for an Imperial as far as body goes with light fizzy carbonation.  Not bad, but I think I was looking for a bit more from this beer given the boastful commercial description.

650ml bottle. Clear darkest brown with small, frothy to creamy, lasting, lacing, tan head. Intense grassy hop aroma, green onions, a touch of fruit, underlying dark malty notes, hints of roast and coffee. Bottle. Pours black with a tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, citrus hops, some floral and cheesy notes. Flavor is sweet and fruity with some roasted malt, chocolate, floral and citrus hops with some caramel. Medium body, average carbonation.

Aroma is both smoky and hoppy - got me doing a Pavlovs dog - with hints of mocha and molasses. Stockholm Beer 2012: trevlig doft och smak. Ganska "mörk" med tydlig humle, lakrits och frukt. Kanske lite kort eftersmak.

A three-way vertical between Lakefront IBA (India-Style Black Ale), Three Heads Skunk Black IPA, and Hoppin Frog Hop Heathen Imperial Black Ale.  Bottle and served in one of my numerous Duvel snifters: Appearance: All three have basically the same color, very deep brown nearly opaque. The difference is head retention with the Three Heads maintaining a fluffy head and producing the best lacework (5). The Lakefront had a slight better head and spotty lace (3) versus the Hop Hopping Frog which left almost no lace on the glassware (2).  The nose: Resiny, bile, oniony hops with some pale chocolate and roast for the Lakefront. Juicy, grassy, piney and a tad faint hop with a dusty roasted malt note for the Skunk. The Hop Heathen is most unique for sure with a grapefruity, piney and smoky earthy malt vapour. Almost meaty and oh so earthy. I love the aroma of the Hopping Frog (9), while the Three Heads is tame and weak but not offensive (7) and the Lakefront has the oniony, garlic, and catty overtones I do not care much for (5).  The taste profiles: We start with the Hop Heathen this time and I get quite a bit of heavy resin, pine sap, and some of the catty high alpha notes that were much more noticeable on the aroma of the Lakefront. There is a nice roasted and slight smoked, leathery, tobacco, liquorice undertones as well for the Hoppin Frog. It is complex for the genre, perhaps too much so. (7). The Skunk has more a basic fruity, piney, and cardboardy taste. Much like the aroma this beer is tame and weak compared to the other two. Even the finish is far too short (5). The Lakefront has a nice bitterness but is still not quite as aggressive as I would like, a bit too malty (but not sweet). Coffee and earth are pronounced with this beer. (6) Mouth feel/Palate: Start with the Three Heads Shunk this time: Lively enough, too much (which explains the lasting head), over carbonated, thin, ashy, short. Not all that good (2) The HFHHIBA (haha) is aggressive, biting, a tad boozy, and a tad medicinal. This one suffers from being the one that is a tad under-carbonated. (3). Then there is the Lakefront IBA which a bit thin and a bit over carbonated as well. There is a minerally and metallic quality about this I found a bit off-putting (2). Wow, NONE OF THESE are clean nor properly carbonated, either over or under. All have major flaws on the palate IMO. <insert sad face emotion here>:  Final Verdict: None of the beers are something I would buy again. Each failed to meet expectations. Each are classic examples of when a brewer attempts the "next big thing" without a clue on what they are doing.  (Remind me not to but a Berliner Weiss from any of these three breweries.). Off to find a good beer and dump the remainder of these bomber, such a waste of my time and monies.

650 ml bottle

This particular black IPA was not my cup of tea but is still a fine beer. It wasnt difficult to finish off the bottle despite it being filling and a little heavy by the end. Dont let this one sit around - drink it fresh and enjoy a superb experiment.

Aroma / Appearance - The inky black fluid pour clings to the sides of the glass. A billowing musty brown head looks like a pile of dead leaves that have crumbled into dust. Anise, chocolate, spruce, and resin spark the inner hophead.

Flavor / Palate - The resin manifests itself immediately in the form of a piney bite. Dark high quality chocolate and anise rise up before a soft feel of ethanol infuses the palate in warmth. The last experience is of a bitter finish that sticks on the back of the throat. I cant wait to try the new Goose Juice and see if Hoppin Frog can carry their momentum to another gem.

Fresh bottle from Jungle Jims. Holy crap this was good. Poured like a full-on porter including a big, foamy khaki head. Big resiny, hop aroma and some darker malt too. Pours a murky, muddy dark brown with some milk chocolate highlights when held up to the light. It almost appears gritty. A careful pour results into a modest two finger creamy tan head with moderate lacing. Not the worlds prettiest beer but thats not the point.

This is one of those beers that captures your attention right away based on the wafting aromas present during the initial pour. Its one of the most complex noses Ive come across. Waves of subtle pine interplay with a more complex aroma of a bright, acidic coffee similar to a fine Kenyan AA. This is followed by a roasty caramel and just a hint of tobacco. Simply amazing!

After experiencing the aroma,  I take my first sip with great anticipation.a damn it doesnt let me down! The first thing I detect is a smooth milk chocolate. The milk chocolate sweetness exits upon the first bitter bite of those beautiful hops. The hops just sit there mid palate begging to stay a few seconds longer. Then comes the big finish of roasty coffee and subtle smokiness, which completely dominate the palate until the next sip.

Mouthfeel is dead on for this style. A soft level of carbonation plays perfectly into a creamy and slightly sticky mouthfeel.

Overall, I cant say enough good things about this beer. Ive had 2-3 other black IPAs and was left with the thought that maybe its just not my style. Then the Heathen came into my life. The aroma and taste are so complex I could see having a slightly different experience with each bottle. Another world-class offering from Hoppin Frog.
)

Bottle: The aroma consists of big pine notes, dark chocolate, black licorice, and a hint of grapefruit. It pours a dark brown with some orange highlights and a small beige head. The flavor starts with a quick dose chocolate and caramel. The finish has some pine and vanilla. Its medium bodied with mild carbonation and a soft mouthfeel.

Bottle. Super hoppy nose. Pours a very dark brown, but not quite black. The taste is nice and smooth, exactly what I expect from a black iipa. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Roasted chocolate aromas. Chocolate and hop flavors. Medium bodied. Good lacing. Overall a very good black IPA.

Bomber, Black as advertised, coffee and leather(?) notes on first sniff, big coffee and chocolate notes on first sip, half finger head with a vigorous pour, pancake appearance from above with some big bubbles, medium body, not much on the finish. 8.8 ABV is well hidden. I would prefer a BIPA to a IBA.
Poured from a 22 ounce bomber thanks to Amy. Poured dark black with minimal head. Tastes like a hopped up brown porter. Sweet caramel malts, slight roast, huge American hop profile. A nice  BIPA.
Bottle. Pours almost black with a tan head. Aroma is hops with toasted malt and coffee. Taste has nice hop bitterness, espresso, toast, and chocolate. Medium to full bodied. Very nice.

22oz bottle 5/20/12 (Binnys Downers Grove)-46° in Shaker-Pours black with a two finger tan head. Aroma of hops, roasted malt, and a little coffee. Taste of the same with more hops and coffee coming through. This medium to full bodied brew is well balanced and quite delicious.

Bomber from Binnys Arlington Heights. Pours near black with tan heas. Aroma is awesome with fresh hops, citrus pine, chocolate, and roasted malt. Flavors of sweet chocolate. sweet roasted malts, pine. light citrus, and light bitterness. If this beer had more hop bitterness it would be great. For a black IPA this is pretty solid.
Dark brown color with a tan head and lots of lacing. Aroma of piney hops and roasted malts. Taste is very hoppy with roasted and some chocolate malts. Finishes hoppy and roasty.

pours black with reddish hues when held to light. Creamy dissipating one finger head. Aroma of some earthy hops and dark malts, maybe some faint bitter dark chocolate. Medi bodied. Tons of chocolatey flavor slightly offset by some Hoppiness. This is quite impressive. As you get more into the beer, it becomes a lot like hoppy chocolate milk, which I love.

Bottle shared by Brett, pour is nicely black and nose is huge and hoppy but after the initial hop bite it subdues to a roasty toasty almost burnt finish which really lingers, after 10 to 15 minutes I could still taste the almost burnt flavor.

UPDATED: JUL 25, 2012 Shared bomber poured to snifters at Lunar Brewing Co., Thanks, Jack! Displayed a darkest brown color with some ruby highlighting noticeable at the base, a modest layer of tan foam that diminished quickly to a thin ring & film, and left some spotty lacing. The nose was roasty, espresso, cocoa, some citrus & resin, mellow smoke & char, and earthy & herbal notes. The flavor was similar but not as expressive, adding a little tartness, moderate but lingering hop bitterness, soft carbonation, and a medium+ body. Alcohol was present but subdued, and the finale was bitter and dry. Next time, another bomber at Lunar. Thanks Taps! The head was more lasting and laced well, the flavor added a little sweetness & carmelization, and the body seemed fuller. +.2

22 ounce bottle.  Served in a pint glass, the beer pours dark brown/black with about a half inch tan head.  Head retention and lacing are both good.  The brew smells like pine and citrusy (grapefruit) hops, roasted malt, bittersweet chocolate, and some coffee.  I think the taste is pretty much just like the aroma, but the flavors seem to be stronger overall in comparison to the aroma.  Theres also a nice lingering bitter hoppy and roasty finish.  Good balance between the hops and malt in both the aroma and flavor.  Mouthfeel/body is medium, its coating and a bit sticky with moderate carbonation.  Overall, I think its a very good brew.  $9.99 a bottle, Id certainly buy this again in the future.

22 oz. pour.  This beer pours black with a thick tan head that nearly coats the glass.  The aroma centers around chocolate and spicy hops, nice roast presence.  I get notes of mint, fresh bakery goods, girl scout thin mint cookies.  Flavor has strong chocolate and mint.  I get medium bitterness, mild sweetness, strong roast.  Some salty notes as well.  Fresh piney and citrus hops are plentiful.  Big, full bodied, nice carbonation.  Finishes bitter and roasty, with plenty of pine.  Nice Black IPA.  One of the best Ive ever had.

Bottle @ Dans house, courtesy of a generous trader. Grazie! Dark brown/black appearance with a light brown head. Piney, sprucey, minty, roasty dark chocolate malty aroma. Fairly bitter, dull piney hoppy, slightly herbal, dull chocolate flavor. The aroma is excellent but the flavor leaves something to be desired.

Pour out of 22 oz bottle, thanks Aaron for the pour! Dark brownish black pour with nice thin tan head, aroma brings notes of big pine, resin, grapefruit, citrus, lemon and orange notes, hints of grassy and slight floral notes, touch of roast and chocolate.  Taste is slightl caramel, chocolate, hints of slight pine, grass notes, slight spice with some onion and garlic, finishing fairly sweet, slightly bitter.  Interesting, but a bit off.

22 oz. bottle via trade with bittermestupid - Pours a deep brown color with a one finger thick light tan head.  Light lacing.  Aroma is resin and pine hops, and lightly roasted malt.  Flavor is lightly roasted malt, chocolate, and pine hops.  Nicely balanced at this point.  Medium body.  A very nice beer.  Thanks Greg.

Bottle from Jeff - thanks!  Black pour with a medium depth tan head that fades down quickly to a slick of foam.  Aroma is sharp resinous pine (maybe some citrus) over a dense, roasted malt backbone that includes some bitter chocolate, a dusting of coffee, and light char.  Taste is a balanced presentation of pine/hop bitterness with a smooth, complex and heavily roasted malt profile that includes tobacco, coffee, bitter chocolate, and a bit of spice.  Mouthfeel is clean and smooth overall with just enough carbonation in the right places to accentuate the bitterness and spice.  Damn - this is impressive!  Ill give it a slight edge over the Wookey Jack simply because the malt profile on this beer is more in line with my personal tastes.

Very black pour with a light head. Very roast aroma that boarders on astringent. Fairly complex flavor with roast, citrus, carbon astringecy, coffee and a solid grain presence. Medium body with a drying mouth feel. Good.

Delicious aroma of roasted chocolate paired with pine notes, there is a hint of alcohol there as well.  Pours an opaque black, with a full light tan head.   This is an amazing beer, slick mouthfeel, low carbonation, and a well balanced battle between roasted notes and hop presence.   This is another solid beer from Hoppin Frog, and Ill be picking up more of this before it disappears off the shelf.

Bomber thanks to Bigmmartin. Pours a pure black color with a small white head (initially a large head). A sweet nose of fruity hops, some roast and caramel. A rich spicy and bitter flavor balanced by chocolate malts and light roast, very smooth and much like the Dubhe from Uinta. Light oranges. Very nice. Lingering bitterness.

Bomber. Impatient guy that I am, I opened this when it was still not completely chilled. Well call it cellar temperature. Pour is dark brown and releases a huge tan head on the first pour, but the rest of it chilled further and the second glass was less rambunctious. Aromas are a punch to the nose of resin and grapefruit that later thin out a bit and become more lemony. Flavor was a surprise. I wasnt expecting that heavy of a chocolate presence, but it is in full force and balances nicely against the spruce forest hoppiness. ABV is high enough to give a slight warmth down the throat and finish is nice and resiny. Great stuff again, Fred!
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: This is my first experience with Hoppin Frog even though I have lived near Akron for almost two years. Shame on me! This beer poured a thick black and contained some particles in it that showed it was unfiltered. This is not the most beautiful beer you will ever lay your eyes on. The aroma and taste will make up for the appearance! This beer has great balance and is just what it says, Imperial Black Ale. This is not a Black IPA. It is merely a hoppy black ale.

Bottle shared by jmborggren. Poured black color with an average frothy brown head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Moderate to heavy toasted malt, chocolate, hop with a small alcohol aroma. Medium body with a dry slick texture and flat carbonation. Medium to heavy dark bittersweet flavor with a medium to heavy bittersweet finish of moderate to long duration. This is a very good complex beer.

Pours blackish brown, decent tan head that persists. Nose is distinct, cocoa puffs, cereal, smoke, roasted malts, coffee and subtle pine hops. Flavors are herbal malt, bitter chocolate bitterness, spice and dry long finish. Some alcohol on the finish. This developed nicely as it warmed. Balanced and quite good

Bottle to oversized snifter. Looks good; black with decent lacing. Smells solid too; bitter and malty. Tastes decent, but Im picking up some soy. Mouthfeel is average. Decent, but not worth spending too much effort to get.

Bottle sample at the Elevator tasting at Ale Wine & Spirits on 4/13/12. Clear brown pour with a medium tan head. Roasty nose with lots of spicy and piney hops. Malty flavor with slight caramel before an oniony hop finish.

22oz bottle, shared with robotopera. Great light brown head. Good lace. Opaque black color. Nice light and crisp carbonation. Big body, dry texture. Nice herbal big hop aroma. The chocolate malt is definitely there, and its almost as big as the hop. Its actually... A good balance, which makes this a very interesting ale. Awesome bitterness, some spice and sweetness. Very tasty. One of the best beers Ive had in a while.

A great idea that made it from concept to kettle to bottle to glass.
A dual identity beer that does not suffer from split personality.
The Frog has captured my desire to have a dark beer with the right color, carbonation and flavors that meld not fight to satisfy my palate.
Drank craft beer fromNew hampshire to New Mexico that do not rival this distinct taste that works my palate without offending my senses.  I can drink more than one of these at a session.  I have a cultivated taste without being a beer nazi.  Well done Hoppin Frog!

This brew pours dark brownish-black with a medium tan head that dissipates steadily. Rings of lacing on the glass. Aroma of hops, pine and roasted malt. Medium body with a roasty character and notes of resiny hops, pine and sweet malt. The finish is hoppy with a toasty malt aftertaste. Solid Black IPA all around.

Pours jet black with tan head and moderate lacing.  Aroma is dominated by powerful pine hops and a touch of citrus hops.  Taste starts like a porter and ends like a spicy Black IPA.  Wow.  This one packs a punch.

Bottle from Dorothy Lane.  As usual for this brewer big funky aromatic hops, in front of a Guiness with snoke and dried fruits.  A lingereing bitterness.  Slightly cloudy coke color, no head but some lacing
